fields.description:
In previous versions of Stash the LDAP synchronization time display automatically refreshed, but in this current version the synchronization time does not update. This is only a minor inconvenience, but our ldap sync sometimes takes 300-400 second and it would be better to watch the time update without manually refreshing.

This is caused by the JavaScript failing to find the {{"synchronisation-started"}} template
fields.summary: LDAP Synchronization Time Refresh Broken due to JavaScript error

fields.description:
If I review pullrequests within stash, I would like to have an opportunity to mark my comments.
I could think of 3 categories.
- Bug/Critical,
- Would be nice to do
- Optional

For instance, there are 50 comments within my pullrequest, it would be a nice feature to see if most of the comments are just optional or if there are a few bugs.
fields.summary: Categories for comments on pullrequest

fields.description: GitHub allow to view pull requests to unlicensed users. Stash is not allowed. You can see repo, but you can't look into pull requests.
fields.summary: Allow to view Pull Reqiests without LICENSED_USER permission

fields.description:
Similar to STASH-2748, it would be beneficial to see how many open pull requests another person has.  This would be beneficial for when selecting reviewers, so that I can avoid someone who is overloaded.

Keywords: count, busy, reviewer, suggest, number, how many
fields.summary: Provide ability to see how many open pull requests another person has

fields.description:
The support tools plugin should include {{stash-config.properties}} in the support zip (when that option is checked). 

In Stash 3.2.0 that config file was moved from STASH_HOME to STASH_HOME/shared. STP needs to be updated to look for the file in the new location.
fields.summary: Include stash-config.properties in support zip

fields.description:
Example: https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/UN/repos/user-management/pull-requests/135/diff#pom.xml

I would expect that if I focus outside of the diff, I should be able to scroll up to the PR details or the top bar without scrolling the diff all the way to the top of the files.
fields.summary: When viewing side-by-side diff in a PR, unable to scroll the page independently of the diff
Account creation notification is localized to the creators locale, instead of the servers default locale

fields.description:
We have a repository with a review gated merge policy (requires 2 reviewers to approve before merge to master is allowed). I recently branched another developers feature branch and made changes, I created a pull request so that they would get a notification that they should merge and update their branch. However... what happened was that stash then required two reviewers to approve the PR. The gated reviewer stetting is global in a repo.

Imo, it is desirable to whitelist / blacklist branches for requiring review. In my case we would whitelist 'master' as the only one requiring review. Going the other way, globs would be useful, e.g. blacklist 'feature/*' as not requiring review.
fields.summary: Allow merge checks such as minimum reviewers to be configured by branch type or pattern

fields.description:
Hello.  I was wondering why Stash use in a production/enterprise environment is only supported on Linux.  Saw this here:  https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+Stash+in+the+enterprise

"Although Stash can be run on Windows, Linux and Mac systems, for enterprise use we only recommend, and support, Linux. This recommendation is based on our own testing and experience with using Stash."

I tried to find out  more info in the FAQ, but did not find any more info/details on this.

Thanks
fields.summary: Why is Stash use for an enterprise enviroment only supported on Linux?

fields.description:
I often use JIRA's 'Create Branch' link to create a branch in Stash, but I would love the Repository selector to be wider, so I can actually read which repo I'm going to create the branch in.

Currently it's pretty small and could be 2x as wide easily.
fields.summary: Please make Repository selector in Create Branch wider

fields.description:
The documented [branch ordering algo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Automatic%20branch%20merging#Automaticbranchmerging-Branchorderingalgorithm] claims to use semantic versioning, but then states that:

bq. if both tokens are numeric, a simple ASCII comparison is used.

If this were true, 1.10 would be ordered before 1.2, which I hope is not the case. Plus this is already contradicted in the previous bullet:

bq. Branches are ordered by number, if a given token is numeric.

Perhaps it's meant to be documenting the "both tokens are _non_-numeric" case?
fields.summary: Documentation of semantic versioning behaviour is wrong

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

[Bitbucket Server Audit Logging|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html#BitbucketServerconfigproperties-Audit] only allows you to enable audit logging in batches. Enterprise customers sometimes need strict auditing on specific events but can't afford the performance impact of setting audit logging to LOW and enabling auditing of every event.

h3. Suggested Solution

Specify certain events that are enabled for auditing with rest endpoints or a bitbucket property. 

h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Make audit event logging more flexible

fields.description:
_and earlier versions_

There were two other issues referencing Stash and Umask - STASH-3088 and STASH-4781 - neither of those seemed to address my (minor) annoyance.

Every time I start Stash up I'm chided with this pesky message that contradicts itself, is incorrect, and while fearful of ridicule by bringing it up ultimately quite annoying. The message goes something like this:

{quote}
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Stash is being run with a umask that contains potentially unsafe settings.
The following issues were found with the mask "u=rwx,g=rx,o=" (0027):
 - access is allowed to 'others'. It is recommended that 'others' be denied
   all access for security reasons.
 - write access is allowed to 'group'. It is recommend that 'group' be
   denied write access. Read access to a restricted group is recommended
   to allow access to the logs.
 - full access has been denied to 'user'. Stash cannot be run without full
   access being allowed.

The recommended umask for Stash is "u=,g=w,o=rwx" (0027) and can be
configured in setenv.sh
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
{quote}

Now - I'm as attentive as the next guy WRT security warnings and ones I have to continually ignore BTF out of me. looking at two lines in the message:
# The following issues were found with the mask "u=rwx,g=rx,o=" (0027):
# The recommended umask for Stash is "u=,g=w,o=rwx" (0027) and ...(more on the rest of this sentence later)

The UNIXy deal taking care of comparing the UMASK value isn't XORing the mask (at first guess) to get it's opposite prior to listing out all the criminally insane permissions said UMASK would unleash upon the unsuspecting world. 

Like I said initially, this is but a piffle of an issue but one more I think you should put on the list as being 'worthy'. 

Thanks,
-wc

oh yea - environment is ubuntu server 13.10 and the 'proper' (i.e. Mark Shuttleworth _approved_ _sanctioned_ and _whatever_) way to alter the umask for the system (all users) is to modify /etc/login.defs as so:
{code}
sed -ie 's/\(UMASK\s.\)\(0027\)/\1 0027/g' /etc/login.defs
{code}

(_accepting, of course, that the above example is stupid as the value is already set to 0027 and you'd have to look for 3-4 sequential digits instead_)

Of course, Mark (who I don't know, I just dislike his approach to UI options) probably wouldn't like either but oh well. I've beat this poor horse to death. 
-wc
fields.summary: Fix the incorrect & pesky 'stash is runnin with a scary umask' message on startup

fields.description:
I'd like to see a feature that allows me to put repositories or complete projects into a "disabled" mode without deleting them.
This is usefull if a project is not developed further but the repo' is to be kept for reference or maintenance purpose or the project might be developed further in the future.

The "disabled" mode should disable all commits to the repo's and hide the projects/repositories from the projects/repositories list (at least by default).
Only admins should be able to set or unset this "disabled" mode. Optionally, it should be up to the settings wether or not it would still be possible to read from to the respective repositories.
fields.summary: Put projects or repositories in sleep / expired mode

fields.description:
Since we're not likely to implement Manage Users Locally in the near future, this ticket now represents the suggestion to disable it in the meantime so as to avoid confusion.

-------------------------------------------
Original description:

When creating a User Directory in Stash using:
- Microsoft Active Directory
- LDAP

The following option is shown in the "Advanced" section:
- 'Manage User Status Locally' - _If true, you can activate and deactivate users in Crowd independent of their status in the directory server._

However, we are currently unable to manage the user status using the Stash UI and that's due to the fact we haven't implemented read/write support for Crowd directories. 

If customers create their UD with 'Manage User Status Locally' option checked, they should expect their instance not to keep up-to-date with changes to the users status on their LDAP servers linked to Stash.

We also need to update our Stash LDAP documentation to include the explanation for that option under the "Advanced" section: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Connecting+Stash+to+an+existing+LDAP+directory

We currently have it documented in Crowd:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Deleting+or+Deactivating+a+User
{quote}
In other words, if a user account is disabled in Active Directory, it will be deactivated in Crowd on the next synchronisation. Likewise, if a user is deactivated through Crowd, the user account will be disabled in Active Directory. If you want to prevent this synchronisation, enable the '*Manage User Status Locally*' option in the directory configuration.
{quote}
fields.summary: Disable "Manage User Status Locally" in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
The suggestion is to allow to create a Fork of an empty repository. 

The objective is to avoid people having direct references to the parent repository, as currently it is necessary to commit something to it before being able to create a Fork.

E.g. currently the project creator needs to create a reference to the master, commit the content, create the fork, then go change the remote reference. If the user forget to change the remote reference, then he will be committing against master.
fields.summary: Ability to Fork empty repositories

fields.summary: Missing unique constraint on id_sequence table

fields.description:
There exists some demand for the ability to support mirroring of repositories across geographies (and therefore Stash instances). This could take a number of forms:
* Read-only mirror
* Transparent proxy
* Two-way mirror
* other...

---- Original request ----
In our company we want to use cascading git repositories:

We have Repo1 on Server A.
Now I want to clone Repo1 on a Stash-managed Server B.
Any developer near to Server B clone Repo1 from Server B on their local maschines.

Are there any possibilities to realize this scenario?
At this moment I'm not able to create a "normal" repository within Stash.
fields.summary: Support mirroring of repositories for geographically distributed teams

fields.description:
We have a few different APIs for plugins to reject some but not all of the changes that can occur with refs - merge checks, pre-receive hooks, etc.

Ideally there would be a single way for plugins to reject any and all changes to a ref.

h2. Possible solution

Introduce a {{RepositoryRefsChangeRequestedEvent}} interface and {{AbstractRepositoryRefsChangeRequestedEvent}} abstract class

- We would fire this event anywhere that a ref is changed (and plugins would be required to do the same when they update a ref).
- Any plugin could listen to this to prevent any ref change within Stash, regardless of whether it's from a push, merge, branch creation, etc.
fields.summary: An API through which plugins can listen to and reject arbitrary changes to refs.

fields.description:
After restart of Stash the SSH access is disabled, i.e. it is not possible to clone any repository using the SSH-protocol, despite the setting being enabled before the restart.

The setting in the server shows that SSH should be enabled but no port on the host machine is showing any process attached to the port we have chosen. Unchecking the box and then re-enabling it solves the problem. After the next restart the same unchecking/checking procedure must be performed by our administrators.

User SSH-keys are provided and works. The user accounts used when the problem occurred the first time were already working with SSH, and as soon as the settings checkbox has been re-enabled the SSH starts working.

The problem occurred after an upgrade from 2.10.3 to 3.1.1. As I recall it the test system we used did not show any of this behaviour. We did not use live data though, and the current 3.1.1 is working as expected when the SSH feature has been re-enabled.
fields.summary: SSH access disabled after restart

fields.description:
We are currently using JIRA and Stash outside of LDAP, and getting users to register when invited.  The age-old problem for us, is when you leave users to do their own thing, they do stupid things.  The common one is to use different usernames when creating their Stash account to their JIRA account.

It doesn't help that the two products work totally differently for creating users:

Stash, the administrator creates the user, the user sets his password.
JIRA, the user is just invited and sets both.

When the usernames don't match, then the Stash and JIRA integration fails to work correctly.

For example, clicking a linked JIRA issue in a pull request page shows an error that the JIRA issue can't be found.

Setting the usernames to match fixes this problem, but it gives the impression that the product lacks polish.

Surely a better way of identifying the same user would be the email address, which is always going to be the same (at least in a corporate environment).
fields.summary: Stash - JIRA Integrations fail when usernames don't match.

fields.description:
Our users have REPO_WRITE permissions, because they work in own branches, which should be pushed on server finally. We have restricted branch naming with pre-receive hook. It works if user pushes branch from local repository. But some curious users found out that they could "Create branch" from interface, and pre-receive hook does not work in this case. It seems to be right, because branch creating is not push. But Stash server contain only bare repositories, so, probably branch firstly created somewhere else and than branch is pushed, so pre-receive hook have to run. So it is critically desirable to have mechanism to restrict branch naming or to run pre-receive hook when branch created from interface. 

Why critically? Because create branch Ab/1/2 and ab/1 breaks repository (Stash could not distinguish Upper/lower case in branches). So we have to restrict it (but not only it, of cause).

from answers https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/324327/how-to-control-create-branch
fields.summary: Pre-Receive hook does not run if "Create Branch" from interface.

fields.description:
Given a repository with both {{refs/heads/release-1.0}} and {{refs/tags/release-1.0}}, Stash shows the branch as follows in the list of branches:

!stash-branch-name.png!

As the page only lists branches, one could argue that it is not necessary or even confusing to disambiguate it like that on this page.

It might also cause the user to try to check it out using {{git checkout -b release-1.0 origin/heads/release-1.0}} which doesn't work. To be fair, {{git checkout release-1.0}} also doesn't work, it checks out the tag. What works is {{git checkout -b release-1.0 origin/release-1.0}}.
fields.summary: Branch with same short name as tag is displayed as "heads/branchname" in branch list
Last parenthesis in URL does not work when it is last character

fields.description:
I report this use-case as a bug, because it does worked in previous versions.
-- 1 --
Navigate in any project/rep and open Branches (from the left panel). Choose any branch. Then press "Create pull-request". You see that Stash suggests base branch as a target branch and nothing as source branch. But in previous versions stash picked up branch from "BranchSelector" on previous page.

It seems not to be  a bug, but the second use case that it does.

-- 2 --
After -- 1 -- press "Back" in browser. You see that "BranchSelector" keeps chosen value. Press "Create pull-request" again. Now you will selected branch as source branch!

-- 3 --
But it is not all. Press "Back" again. Choose another branch.  Press "Create pull-request".You will see as source branch - previous value. 

-- 4 --
If you will press "Back" and "Create pull-request" again stash picks up last value finally. ;)

Screenshots in order of described use-cases.
fields.summary: BranchSelector does not propagate value in PullRequestCreation

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the stash/bamboo integration (and more generally any CI server) automatically build/CI pull requests.

This is similar to STASH-3196, but once stash/bamboo is linked its not possible to watch refs/pull-requests/*/merge.

As a workaround we may end up writing a pullrequestopened/rescoped/closed hook that creates/modifies/deletes a 'real' branch for bamboo to pick up, but it would be good to support this out of the box.

Raised this against Stash rather than Bamboo because I suspect that Stash would have to do the triggering?
fields.summary: Ability to have CI automatically build pull-requests

fields.description:
I would like to see a small workflow on the pull request.  Right now the scenario of the review works well if the pull request is ready to merge, or if the reviewer themselves are making the fix.  However when the pull request has issues that need to be addressed, there should be a state to reflect this.

Something like:

1.) Log pull request
2.) Reviewer(s) nominated
3.) Review does not pass -> Rework required (this is my new suggestion).  This removes the pull request from the reviewer's queue and puts it back onto the submitter's queue.
4.) Submitter fixes review comments and then marks defect as ready for review (which is new also, which would put the pull request back onto the reviewer's queue).
5.) pull request reviewed again and accepted
6.) request is then merged automatically or manually.

Right now, if I fail a review from one of my developers, then I cannot notify them via Stash that they need to review the item.  Secondly the item remains in my queue, even though I have actually reviewed the issue.
fields.summary: Pull Request needs a "Rework" status

fields.description: Provide means to automatically build and configure Stash server using Puppet automation. Configuring all the global server settings including license information, connection to external DB, user directories LDAP delegation profile
fields.summary: Build Stash Server using Puppet

fields.description:
If a PR to a main branch of a repo originates in a personal fork the PullRequestRescopedEvent is not fired when the branch in the personal fork is updated.

To reproduce 
* create a personal fork, 
* install the https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.plugin.stash-auto-unapprove-plugin/versions addon, 
* enable the unapprove hook for the main repo
* create PR from the fork to a main repo branch, add a couple of reviewiers, approve ...

and update the source branch of the PR.

>> The approval is not withdrawn.
fields.summary: PullRequestRescopedEvent not fired for personal forks

fields.description:
{quote}We have Crowd and stash users/group is managed in Crowd server. We have setup 60 min as synchronization interval to get the updated password and users from Crowd. This is OK and working fine, some users need the password update as soon it is done in crowd.
Is there any way I can automate the synchronize from crowd -> Stash using a REST call , so that users can run after they change the password in crowd.{quote}
fields.summary: Synchronize User directory using REST API

fields.description:
After we upgraded to Stash 3.2 all our existing README.md files look less readable than they did before.

The change seems to be that 3.2 does not have any whitespace below the last paragraph of a multi paragraph list item. Example:
{noformat}
1. Here's list item 1

    Here's paragraph 1 of the first list item

    Here's paragraph 2 of the first list item

1. Here's list item 2
{noformat}
The last paragraph of list item 1 and list item 2 will not have any whitespace between them, which they did in the previous version.
fields.summary: The formatting of multi paragraph list items have changed

fields.description:
For pull requests with a lot of files and when multiple iterations are needed to get it merged it is only workable to have a filter to only show the files with updates. 

That way the reviewer can directly see which files he/she has to review again without going through the whole list. 

That list is not always completely uncollapsed which makes it troublesome to go through the whole review again.
fields.summary: Ability to only show the updated files in a pull request for that user.

fields.description:
Verification of CAPTCHA is broken on Stash 3.2. The problem is indirectly caused by use of Hazelcast's session replication. Hazelcast wraps the Tomcat HttpSession with its own wrapper, which has a different session ID.

When the Captcha challenge is created, the captcha token is stored against the session ID obtained from HttpSession.getId(). However, when the provided token is verified, it's retrieved using HttpServletRequest.getRequestedSessionId() which differs. Therefore the token is not found and an error occurs.
fields.summary: Captcha verification is broken in 3.2

fields.description:
It would be really nice for Stash to have better integration with git flow (http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/) like it does for release branches.

In Stash, we can specify release, hotfix, feature, and bugfix branches in the Branching Model page in the repository settings, but Automatic Merging only affects the release branches.

The git flow model specifies that hotfix branches must also merge back into both develop and master. Right now, I have to make two pull requests, one into develop and one into master.

More broadly, it would be nice for Stash to have Git Flow buttons (e.g. "Finish Hotfix") like SourceTree does that would automatically generate a pull request into the correct branch(es).
fields.summary: Automatic merging should have better integration with the git flow model

fields.description: If we focus diff view by default, adding a counter badge to the commits tab will allow you to quickly eyeball if the number of commits looks roughly correct.
fields.summary: Add counter badge to commits tab on compare view

fields.description: I usually go to the compare view to do comparison. The diff is the most important piece of information.
fields.summary: Diff should be default tab for compare view

fields.description:
If a filename contains a \ (backslash) character in the file name, Stash will error with "An unknown error has occurred" when trying to view the file from the "Commits" tab.

*Steps to Reproduce*

# Commit a file with \ in the file name and push to the Stash server
# In Stash click on *Commits*
# Select the commit
# Error message will be displayed

!Screen Shot 2014-08-06 at 4.13.12 PM.png|width=800!

If viewing the file from the source tab, a blank page is displayed.
fields.summary: Filenames with backslash cause "An unknown error has occurred"

fields.description:
Current Design:

- The first item always shows as selected - it is the keyboard focus
- Any item you hover shows as selected - it is the mouse focus
- The item that is the actual value of the selector is not visually shown.

E.g. If items A B and C are in the list, in that order, and C is selected, and your mouse is over B:
- A will show as selected because it is the first item
- B will show as selected because your mouse is over it
- C won't show as selected, because it doesn't have any focus

This has confused customers who expect to see the currently selected item given some visual focus indicator.
fields.summary: Repository and branch selectors shown confusing highlighted items

fields.description:
The line comments in pull requests seem to be tied to fixed line numbers within the source file, they do not move together with the line when file updates change line numbers.
An example for how this causes problems:
# Comment is added to line X.
# Changes pushed add Y lines to the file, before line X.
# Comment is still on line X (which has completely different content now), instead of line X+Y which now contains the source code the comment was made about.
fields.summary: Line Comments in pull requests tied to fixed line numbers

fields.description:
When someone forks a repository (into their user space) and makes a pull request to the original repository, there is no good way to review the changes locally, i.e. in a local checkout of the original repository. You could clone the private repository of the PR requester, but you might not even have full access to it. Another workaround is to edit the PR and choose a different target branch (which can be fetched and reviewed before merging into the actual target branch), but that is (1) cumbersome and (2) "decouples" the final (decisive) merge from the PR.

Suggestion: In a PR coming from a different repository, offer the possibility to "Fetch as local branch". That local branch has to be given a name; a few quick choices could be offered, e.g. "pull-requests/<id>", "[pull-requests/]<user-name>/<other-repo-name>/<branch-name>".

Some sort of integration of this with SourceTree would be nice as well.
fields.summary: Allow fetching of a branch in a pull request from a forked repository

fields.description:
We're using an external pre-receive hook to trigger our own perl script. In this script we have rule:
If user create a branch and push it to remote where branch name not match pattern (only alphanumeric, hyphen and underscore characters) the hook reject push.
Right now we have a problem: If user create a branch from Stash GUI, the plugin allowed create new branch without any allowed characters rule. After user clone repo and push that branch to remote repo, the hook reject push.

How we can set pattern for branch name in Stash?

I thinking about create a new plug-ins to listening BranchCreatedEvent. If new branch name not match pattern, we'll cancel it.

Please, give me a clue if I'm on right way. 
Do you know how I can resolve this problem in other way?

fields.description:
after updating from version 3.0.4 to 3.1.3 I started noticing that many pull requests are "stuck" because of conflicts while there are no conflict in practice (checking it locally via git confirms it).

"*This pull request can't be merged.* You will need to resolve conflicts to be able to merge"

this issue really slows my flow and gets everyone very irritated.
fields.summary: creating a new pull request creates a false conflict message

fields.description:
bin/permgen.sh contains the following lines - probably set by the linux installer:
{noformat}
# DO NOT remove the following line
JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.7.0-openjdk-1.7.0.55.x86_64/jre"; export JAVA_HOME
{noformat}

That specific version of the JDK got removed here via a yum update (moved to 1.7.0.65).

h4. Possible solution

Instead of setting the JAVA_HOME in permgen.sh, save it in {{/etc/environment}} or {{~/.profile}} when it's not specified. This lets customer continue using their system JRE (gives more control and won't needlessly bloat their system), but without the risk of overwriting changes in the JAVA_HOME variable during Stash startup. This is more inline with the instructions we use when manually installing Stash, as well.
fields.summary: permgen.sh keeps reference to non-existing JAVA_HOME

Actaul: Permission lozange doesn't change until the page is reloaded. (This is just cosmetic; the actual permissions for the user are updated)

I found STASH-2538, but that's closed and this is still an issue in 3.1.3.
fields.summary: Update the permission lozenge immediately when adding a user to a group
